projectDesc.p: "The elegant reply of the Florentine poet Dante" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.lem: Dantes Alligerius, poeta noster Florentinus, aliquamdiu sustentatus est Veronae opibus Canis veteris Principis de la Scala, admodum liberalis.
app.rdg: Our Florentine poet Dante Alighieri dwelled for a while in Verona, sustained by the older Cangrande della Scala, a very noble ruler.

app.lem: Erat autem et alter penes Canem Florentinus, ignobilis, indoctus, imprudens, nulli rei praeterquam ad iocum risumque aptus,
app.rdg: However, there was also another Florentine at Cangrande’s, an ignoble, unlearned, and ignorant man, not fit for anything excepts for jokes and laughter.

app.lem: cuius ineptiae, ne dicam facetiae, Canem perpulerant ad se ditandum.
app.rdg: His fooleries (I will not call them jokes!) had made Cangrande enrich him.

app.lem: Cum illum veluti belluam insulsam, Dantes, vir doctissimus, sapiens ac modestus, ut aequum erat, contemneret:
app.rdg: When Dante, who is most learned, wise, and modest, showed contempt for this inelegant beast of a man, which was just, he said:

app.lem: 'Quid est' inquit ille, 'quod tu, cum habearis sapiens ac doctissimus, tamen pauper es et egenus, ego autem stultus et ignarus divitiis praesto?'
app.rdg: “How is it that you, who think yourself wise and very learned, still is poor and destitute, while I, who is stupid and ignorant, am very rich?”

app.lem: Tum Dantes: 'Quando ego reperiam dominum,' inquit, 'mei similem et meis moribus conformem, sicuti tu tuis, et ipse similiter me ditabit.'
app.rdg: To which Dante replied: “When I have found a lord who is like me and my manners, just as you have, then he will reward me in a similar manner.”

app.lem: Semper enim domini eorum consuetudine qui sibi sunt similes delectantur.
app.rdg: For the lords always find pleasure in the habits of those who are like themselves.
